content.raw:
A small bit of this has been addressed in the osx_1.9 branch in [RenderEngine.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/osx_1.9..issue_775_1.9#Lgazebo/rendering/RenderEngine.ccF347T355).

The bigger issue is in specifying plugins in model or world files (e.g. from [hokuyo model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/c74256fec4eb165bb328d758410c12ab4ecf2aa6/hokuyo/model.sdf#cl-55)):
~~~
<plugin name="laser" filename="libRayPlugin.so" />
~~~
Perhaps we should deprecate the `filename` attribute and make a new one called `base_name` (which would have a value of `RayPlugin` for the hokuyo example).
content.html:
A small bit of this has been addressed in the osx_1.9 branch in RenderEngine.cc.

The bigger issue is in specifying plugins in model or world files (e.g. from hokuyo model):

<plugin name="laser" filename="libRayPlugin.so" />

Perhaps we should deprecate the filename attribute and make a new one called base_name (which would have a value of RayPlugin for the hokuyo example).

content.raw:
To follow pluginlib's and ROS's standard, I propose we call it ``type`` instead of ``filename``. 

We could go ahead and implement the logic for the new way and deprecate the old way of specifying plugins.
content.html:
To follow pluginlib's and ROS's standard, I propose we call it type instead of filename.

We could go ahead and implement the logic for the new way and deprecate the old way of specifying plugins.

content.raw: I committed some code to [sdformat in branch gazebo_issue_800](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/compare/gazebo_issue_800..sdf_1.4#diff) that is a first pass at this issue.
content.html: I committed some code to sdformat in branch gazebo_issue_800 that is a first pass at this issue.

content.raw:
What about compiling the plugins with `.so` extension on OS X. [Cmake docs](http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/cmake2.6docs.html) suggest using `MODULE` type when using `add_library` for plugins that are loaded dynamically. The produced library already has `.so` extension on OS X when this type is used.

Moreover the [fink docs](http://fink.thetis.ig42.org/doc/porting/porting.en.html#shared.lib-and-mod) mention `.dylib` files are not supposed to be dynamically loaded.
content.html:
What about compiling the plugins with .so extension on OS X. Cmake docs suggest using MODULE type when using add_library for plugins that are loaded dynamically. The produced library already has .so extension on OS X when this type is used.

Moreover the fink docs mention .dylib files are not supposed to be dynamically loaded.

content.raw: There is a temporary workaround in pull request #925 that automatically replaces `.so` with `.dylib` using an `#ifdef __APPLE__`. I still consider this an open issue as we search for a better solution.
content.html: There is a temporary workaround in pull request #925 that automatically replaces .so with .dylib using an #ifdef __APPLE__. I still consider this an open issue as we search for a better solution.

content.raw:
Interesting.

I did not know about the Mach-O system differentiation between shared libraries and loadable modules. Well in fact in ELF systems, it does not exists. Thanks for the information @muratsevim. I will give a look at cmake documentation.
content.html:
Interesting.

I did not know about the Mach-O system differentiation between shared libraries and loadable modules. Well in fact in ELF systems, it does not exists. Thanks for the information @muratsevim. I will give a look at cmake documentation.

content.raw: The temporary workaround in pull request #925 is in place, while we figure out a better solution, ideally something that would work for Windows as well.
content.html: The temporary workaround in pull request #925 is in place, while we figure out a better solution, ideally something that would work for Windows as well.

content.raw:
To be honest I don't like the solution in [pull request #925](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/925/temporary-fix-for-800-plugin-loading-on).
I think the best way is to let the user specify the full name as before. In (at least) *NIX systems extensions are just hints.

Further more as @muratsevim said, this is taken from CMake documentation:

> SHARED libraries are linked dynamically and loaded at runtime. MODULE libraries are plugins that are not linked into other targets but may be loaded dynamically at runtime using dlopen-like functionality.

And it looks to me that a Module is the right choice, and a shared library is not.
And Mac OS X automatically adds the `.so` extension to the module.
content.html:
To be honest I don't like the solution in pull request #925. I think the best way is to let the user specify the full name as before. In (at least) *NIX systems extensions are just hints.

Further more as @muratsevim said, this is taken from CMake documentation:

SHARED libraries are linked dynamically and loaded at runtime. MODULE libraries are plugins that are not linked into other targets but may be loaded dynamically at runtime using dlopen-like functionality.

And it looks to me that a Module is the right choice, and a shared library is not. And Mac OS X automatically adds the .so extension to the module.

But maybe there's already the fix in version 6.5.1 ?

content.raw: @liohau as of gazebo 2.2, we automatically replace `.so` with `.dylib` inside an `#ifdef __APPLE__` (see pull request #925 or earlier in this comment thread), so I think the error is not related to the suffix. I'll respond to your ROS answers post so we can move the discussion there.
content.html: @liohau as of gazebo 2.2, we automatically replace .so with .dylib inside an #ifdef __APPLE__ (see pull request #925 or earlier in this comment thread), so I think the error is not related to the suffix. I'll respond to your ROS answers post so we can move the discussion there.

content.raw: Ok thanks see you on ROS answers then :)
content.html: Ok thanks see you on ROS answers then :)

content.raw: Digging up this thread because I'm gonna implement this for reals. Windows is an up and coming priority, and this is one of the small things I've noticed along the way. I like the idea of specifying the "type" of the plugin (as @davetcoleman suggested). instead of ```filename=libMyPlugin.so``` just have ```type=MyPlugin``` and the proper prefix/suffix will be added. I'd be ok with ```basename=``` but we should use whatever ROS/Gazebo people would expect.
content.html: Digging up this thread because I'm gonna implement this for reals. Windows is an up and coming priority, and this is one of the small things I've noticed along the way. I like the idea of specifying the "type" of the plugin (as @davetcoleman suggested). instead of filename=libMyPlugin.so just have type=MyPlugin and the proper prefix/suffix will be added. I'd be ok with basename= but we should use whatever ROS/Gazebo people would expect.

content.html: @almin , something to consider when making the design for a plugin database.

content.raw: @peter_mitrano I'm going to finally follow up on the suggestions from @francesco_romano and @muratsevim to build the plugins as `MODULE` libraries instead of `SHARED` libraries. This will actually unify the mac and linux naming, since they will both use `.so`. We should still do the rest though so we can handle `.dll` libraries on windows.
content.html: @peter_mitrano I'm going to finally follow up on the suggestions from @francesco_romano and @muratsevim to build the plugins as MODULE libraries instead of SHARED libraries. This will actually unify the mac and linux naming, since they will both use .so. We should still do the rest though so we can handle .dll libraries on windows.

content.raw: switching to `MODULE` in  97a1f94 (branch issue_800_module), testing now
content.html: switching to MODULE in 97a1f94 (branch issue_800_module), testing now

content.raw:
Ok, that's convenient. It should be a very simple fix, and still useful on
mac, because people building their own plugins may make them as SHARED
instead of MODULE.
content.html: Ok, that's convenient. It should be a very simple fix, and still useful on mac, because people building their own plugins may make them as SHARED instead of MODULE.

@scpeters I think that this is definitively the right choice, but consider that for a long time all the plugins tutorials [1] have been recommending to create plugins as SHARED libraries, so I would expect all the third-party plugins build system to compile their plugins as SHARED (i.e. .dylib in OS X).

However the commit #!/osrf/gazebo/commits/97a1f94 is breaking support for all existing third-party plugins on OS X. Maintaining the compatibility with .dylib plugins for at least one stable release (Gazebo 8) would help saving a lot of troubles to downstream plugin developers and facilitate the migration to MODULE plugins.

[1] : http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=plugins_hello_world&cat=write_plugin

content.raw: @traversaro that's a good point; we'll have make `SHARED` plugins a deprecated functionality with a warning message in gazebo8 before removing it
content.html: @traversaro that's a good point; we'll have make SHARED plugins a deprecated functionality with a warning message in gazebo8 before removing it

content.raw: I've switched to using `MODULE` in pull request #2306 and deprecated the search for `.dylib` libraries.
content.html: I've switched to using MODULE in pull request #2306 and deprecated the search for .dylib libraries.

content.raw:
Hey :),

so in favor of the idea of a plugin database:

We can add .so and .dll files (+ deprecated .dylib) to the plugin database and all of them are searched for and listed in the insert tab, for example. 

Now how do we handle Windows dll. files in our plugin.hh? Should we use an additional hack for this, alike the  #ifdef __APPLE__ hack and replace the .dll with an .so?
content.html:
Hey :),

so in favor of the idea of a plugin database:

We can add .so and .dll files (+ deprecated .dylib) to the plugin database and all of them are searched for and listed in the insert tab, for example.

Now how do we handle Windows dll. files in our plugin.hh? Should we use an additional hack for this, alike the #ifdef APPLE hack and replace the .dll with an .so?

content.raw: I ended up declining pull request #2306, which switched the plugins to `MODULE` since it imposes limitations on linking, we couldn't find any benefits of doing it. Please chime in if it is important to use `MODULE` for plugin libraries.
content.html: I ended up declining pull request #2306, which switched the plugins to MODULE since it imposes limitations on linking, we couldn't find any benefits of doing it. Please chime in if it is important to use MODULE for plugin libraries.
